content:
EXISTING STRUCTURES
─────────────────────
### Extraction System Interface at Position(x=-3.5, y=27.5)
Consists of:
• Extraction system burner inserter with drop position (x=-3.5, y=28.5)
Use-case:
• Serves as the entry point for transferring raw materials from the extraction system onto the transport network.

### Copper Cable Factory Interface at Position(x≈2.5–3.5)
Consists of:
• Cable factory input chest at Position(x=2.5, y=17.5)
• Dedicated burner inserter placed at Position(x=3.5, y=17.5)
Use-case:
• Feeds components into the copper cable production setup and initiates material processing.

### Belt Depot and Connection Network at Position(x≈3.5–4.5, y≈14.5–15.5)
Consists of:
• Belt depot wooden chest at Position(x=3.5, y=15.5) serving as an isolated depot
• Adjacent transport belt segment at Position(x=4.5, y=15.5)
• Depot burner inserter at Position(x=3.5, y=14.5) positioned next to the depot chest
Use-case:
• Acts as an intermediary station that receives items from the extraction system and channels them toward the factory interface via multi‐segment belt connections.

ERROR TIPS
──────────
• Transport Belt Connection Errors (Steps 210, 211, 213, 214, 215, 216, 217)
  – Repeated error: “Transport belts cannot be connected directly to a Prototype.SteamEngine object as a target. You need to add an inserter that inputs items into Prototype.SteamEngine and use the inserter as the target entity.”
  – Mitigation: Verify the target entity type before connecting belts and ensure that an appropriate inserter (not a steam engine) is used as the belt’s endpoint.

• Wooden Chest Placement Errors (Steps 212 and 213)
  – Errors encountered due to:
  • Target position being too far (distance exceeds maximum allowable)
  • Lack of a wooden chest in the inventory during placement
  – Mitigation: Move closer to the target placement location and confirm that the required item (wooden chest) is available in the inventory before attempting placement.

• Naming and Variable Reference Error (Step 212)
  – Error: Undefined variable “target_chest” caused a NameError.
  – Mitigation: Ensure all variables are correctly defined and consistently referenced to avoid scope and naming issues.
